author: Kolten Parker
title: Want to name these adorable otter pups born in New Braunfels? Here's how

ORNELAS, San Antonio Express-News Image 55 of 56 A dead sea otter coated with crude oil from the Exxon Valdez oil spill is found on the beach of Green Island in Prince William Sound, Alaska on April 2, 1989. Nearly 19 years to the day that an Exxon oil tanker hit a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound, the U.S. Supreme Court will hear one of the final lawsuits left lingering from the nation's worst environmental disaster. On Wednesday, February 27, 2008, the court will hear ExxonMobil's appeal, a 14-year effort that, if successful, would overturn a $2.5 billion punitive damage award, one of the largest ever against a U.S. corporation. (Bob Hallinen/Anchorage Daily News/MCT) A dead sea otter coated with crude oil from the Exxon Valdez oil spill is found on the beach of Green Island in Prince William Sound, Alaska on April 2, 1989. Nearly 19 years to the day that an Exxon oil ... more Photo: Bob Hallinen, MCT Image 56 of 56 Want to name these adorable otter pups born in New Braunfels? Here's how 1 / 56 Back to Gallery A New Braunfels zoo is asking Facebook users for help to name four extremely cute newborn otters that were announced over the weekend.
The Animal World and Snake Farm Zoo, located at 5640 Interstate 35, just south of New Braunfels, posted photos of the furry babies on Facebook Sunday and asked readers to "comment below with names for the two baby girls and two baby boys."
RELATED: Gator found swimming in river near Spring Branch finds new home at Animal World and Snake Farm Zoo
The litter of pups were born to mother "Heidi" and father "Emmett," the park said in an email.
"With the suggestion of our veterinarian, our zookeepers are working tirelessly to hand-raise the baby girls who will eventually become animal ambassadors for the zooâ€™s education program," said Hannah Mulligan, a spokeswoman for the zoo. "The other two pupswill remain with their parents and can been seen on exhibit during regular business hours."
Asian small-clawed otters are the world's smallest species of otters and the carnivores are found in the wild in Southeast Asia, according to the Smithsonian National Zoo .
As of Monday at noon, the post had received nearly 300 comments.
Animal World and Snake Farm Zoo, which is accredited by the Zoological Association of America , has more than 500 animals and boasts one of the largest reptile collection on display in Texas.
